body.p: You can use the command line interface to set up a VXLAN provider network and add segmentation ranges.
Note: This feature applies only to servers in the VNF Region.
VXLAN provider networks are an alternative to VLAN provider networks when VM L2 connectivity is required across separate Layer 2 network segments separated by one or more Layer 3 routers.

The steps in this section describe how to set up a VXLAN provider network and add segmentation ranges using the command line interface. For information about using the Horizon interface, see Setting Up a VXLAN Provider Network using Horizon.
To create a provider network using the CLI, use the following command:

ul.li: name is a name for the provider network
type is the type of provider network (flat, vlan, or vxlan
description is a brief description for reference purposes
mtu_size is the maximum transmission unit size

body.p: To add a segmentation range using the CLI, use the following command:

ul.li: provider_network is the name of the associated provider network
name is a name for the segmentation range
tenant is the name or UUID of the tenant associated with the range
description is a brief description for reference purposes
min is the lowest value in the range
max is the highest value in the range

body.p: The following additional values are used for segmentation ranges on VxLAN provider networks:

ul.li: multicast_address The IPv4 or IPv6 address for participation in a multicast group used to discover MAC addresses for destination VMs. You can use a different multicast group for each segmentation range to help organize and partition network traffic.

li.p: udp_port - The destination UDP port for packets sent on the VXLAN. You can select either:

ul.li: the IANA standard 4789 to use this range with the Openstack Neutron service
the legacy standard 8472 for use with some commercial switch equipment.

li.p: time_to_live - The time-to-live, measured in hops, for packets sent on the VXLAN. The value is decremented at each hop; when it reaches zero, the packet expires. You can use this to limit the scope of the VXLAN. For example, to limit the packet to no more than three router hops, use a time-to-live value of 4.

body.p: For more about these parameters, see Setting Up a VXLAN Provider Network using Horizon.
You can obtain information about provider networks and segmentation ranges using the following commands.

codeblock.codeph: neutron net-list-on-providernet providernet neutron providernet-range-show providernet-range
